These appeals have been filed against the judgment of the Madras High Court dated 12.10.2009.

facts.text: Appeals filed against judgment of Madras High Court dated 12.10.2009.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals have been filed against the judgment of the Madras High Court dated 12.10.2009. The appellant herein has alleged that he was married according to the Hindu Customary Rites with one Lakshmi on 25.6.1980.

facts.text: Appellant alleged marriage to Lakshmi according to Hindu Customary Rites on 25.6.1980.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein has alleged that he was married according to the Hindu Customary Rites with one Lakshmi on 25.6.1980. Out of the wedlock with Lakshmi a male child was born, who is now studying in an Engineering college at Ooty.

facts.text: Male child born out of wedlock with Lakshmi, now studying in Engineering college at Ooty.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the wedlock with Lakshmi a male child was born, who is now studying in an Engineering college at Ooty. The petitioner is working as a Secondary Teacher in Thevanga Higher Secondary School, Coimbatore.

facts.text: Appellant working as Secondary Teacher in Thevanga Higher Secondary School, Coimbatore.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is working as a Secondary Teacher in Thevanga Higher Secondary School, Coimbatore. It appears that the respondent-D. Patchaiammal filed a petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. in the year 2001 before the Family Court at Coimbatore in which she alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986

facts.text: Respondent D. Patchaiammal filed petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. in 2001 before Family Court at Coimbatore.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent-D. Patchaiammal filed a petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. in the year 2001 before the Family Court at Coimbatore in which she alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986 and since then the appellant herein and she lived together in her fathers house for two or three years.

facts.text: Respondent alleged marriage to appellant on 14.9.1986.

anchor.surface_text: in which she alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986 and since then the appellant herein and she lived together in her fathers house for two or three years. It is alleged in the petition that after two or three years the appellant herein left the house of the respondents father

facts.text: After marriage on 14.9.1986, appellant and respondent lived together in her father's house for two or three years.

anchor.surface_text: and since then the appellant herein and she lived together in her fathers house for two or three years. It is alleged in the petition that after two or three years the appellant herein left the house of the respondents father and started living in his native place, but would visit the respondent occasionally.

facts.text: Appellant left respondent's father's house after two or three years and lived in native place with occasional visits.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged in the petition that after two or three years the appellant herein left the house of the respondents father and started living in his native place, but would visit the respondent occasionally. It is alleged that the appellant herein respondent in the petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. deserted the respondent herein petitioner

facts.text: Respondent alleged she has no livelihood and unable to maintain herself, appellant draws Rs.10000 per month salary.

anchor.surface_text: In her petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. she alleged that she did not have any kind of livelihood and she is unable to maintain herself whereas the respondent appellant herein is a Secondary Grade Teacher drawing a salary of Rs.10000/- per month.

facts.text: Respondent prayed for Rs.500 per month maintenance from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Hence it was prayed that the respondent appellant herein be directed to pay Rs.500/- per month as maintenance to the petitioner.

facts.text: In petition and deposition, respondent alleged marriage on 14.9.1986 and left after two or three years.

anchor.surface_text: In both her petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. as well as in her deposition in the case the respondent has alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986, and that he left her after two or three years of living together with her in her fathers house.

facts.text: Respondent's own case: appellant left her in 1988 or 1989.

anchor.surface_text: Thus it is the own case of the respondent herein that the appellant left her in 1988 or 1989 i.e. two or three years after the alleged marriage in 1986 . Why then was the petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. filed in the year 2001, i.e. after a delay of about twelve years

facts.text: Petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. filed in 2001, delay of about twelve years from 1988/1989.

anchor.surface_text: Why then was the petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. filed in the year 2001, i.e. after a delay of about twelve years, shall have to be satisfactorily explained by the respondent. This fact also creates some doubt about the case of the respondent herein.

facts.text: Appellant filed counter affidavit before Family Court alleging marriage to Lakshmi on 25.6.1980, male child studying in C.S.I. Engineering college at Ooty, produced ration card, voters identity card of wife, transfer certificate of son, discharge certificate of wife, wedding photographs.

anchor.surface_text: In his counter affidavit filed by the appellant herein before the Family Court, Coimbatore, it was alleged that the respondent appellant herein was married to one Lakshmi on 25.6.1980 as per the Hindu Marriage rites and customs and he had a male child, who is studying in C.S.I. Engineering college at Ooty. To prove his marriage with Lakshmi the appellant produced the ration card, voters identity card of his wife, transfer certificate of his son, discharge certificate of his wife Lakshmi from hospital, photographs of the wedding, etc.

facts.text: Family Court Judge held by judgment dated 5.3.2004 that appellant was married to respondent and not to Lakshmi.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Family Court Judge has held by his judgment dated 5.3.2004 that the appellant was married to the respondent and not to Lakshmi. These findings have been upheld by the High Court in the impugned judgment.

facts.text: Family Court findings upheld by Madras High Court in impugned judgment.

anchor.surface_text: These findings have been upheld by the High Court in the impugned judgment. In our opinion, since Lakshmi was not made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and no notice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis-a-vis the appellant

facts.text: Lakshmi was not made a party and no notice issued to her in Family Court or High Court proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, since Lakshmi was not made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and no notice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis--vis the appellant is wholly null and void as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Family Court and High Court findings that appellant not married to Lakshmi are null and void for violating natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: hence any declaration about her marital status vis--vis the appellant is wholly null and void as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice. Without giving a hearing to Lakshmi no such declaration could have validly be given by the Courts below that she had not married the appellant herein since such as a finding would seriously affect her rights.

facts.text: Matter remanded to Family Court to issue notice to Lakshmi, hear her, and give fresh finding on marriage to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the facts of the present case, we are of the opinion that the High Court and the learned Family Court Judge erred in law in holding that the appellant was not married to Lakshmi without even issuing notice to Lakshmi. Hence this finding has to be set aside and the matter remanded to the Family Court which may issue notice to Lakshmi and after hearing her give a fresh finding in accordance with law.

In our opinion, since Lakshmi was not made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and no notice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis--vis the appellant is wholly null and void as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice. Without giving a hearing to Lakshmi no such declaration could have validly be given by the Courts below that she had not married the appellant herein since such a finding would seriously affect her rights.

concepts.interpretation: Any declaration affecting a person's marital status without issuing notice and giving her a hearing is wholly null and void.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 a  of the Act states 2 a  aggrieved person means any woman who is, or has been, in a domestic relationship with the respondent and who alleges to have been subjected to any act of domestic violence by the respondent

Section 2 f  states 2 f  domestic relationship means a relationship between two persons who live or have, at any point of time, lived together in a shared household, when they are related by companysanguinity, marriage, or through a relationship in the nature of marriage, adoption or are family members living together as a joint family

Section 2 s  states 2 s  shared household means a household where the person aggrieved lives or at any stage has lived in a domestic relationship either singly or along with the respondent and includes such a household whether owned or tenanted either jointly by the aggrieved person and the respondent, or owned or tenanted by either of them

Section 3 a  states that an act will companystitute domestic violence in case it- 3 a  harms or injures or endangers the health, safety, life, limb or well-being, whether mental or physical, of the aggrieved person or tends to do so

An aggrieved person under the Act can approach the Magistrate under Section 12 for the relief mentioned in Section 12 2 . Under Section 20 1  d  the Magistrate can grant maintenance while disposing of the application under Section 12 1 . Section 26 1  provides that the relief mentioned in Section 20 may also be sought in any legal proceeding

The expression domestic relationship includes number only the relationship of marriage but also a relationship in the nature of marriage. The question, therefore, arises as to what is the meaning of the expression a relationship in the nature of marriage. Unfortunately this expression has number been defined in the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Akin to common law marriage: parties must hold out as spouses, be of legal age, qualified to marry, voluntarily cohabited and held out as spouses for significant period, lived together in shared household. Mere sexual relationship or keep does not qualify.

holdings.text: Any declaration about Lakshmi's marital status vis-Ã -vis the appellant without making her a party or issuing notice is wholly null and void as violative of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, since Lakshmi was not made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and no notice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis-- vis the appellant is wholly null and void as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lakshmi affected without opportunity to be heard violates audi alteram partem principle of natural justice.

holdings.text: Without hearing Lakshmi, courts below could not validly declare she had not married the appellant as it affects her rights.

anchor.surface_text: Without giving a hearing to Lakshmi no such declaration could have validly be given by the Courts below that she had not married the appellant herein since such as a finding would seriously affect her rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finding directly impacts Lakshmi's legal rights requiring her participation per natural justice.

holdings.text: No valid declaration that appellant was validly married to respondent possible without validly disproving marriage to Lakshmi.

anchor.surface_text: And if no such declaration could have been given obviously no declaration could validly have been given that the appellant was validly married to the respondent, because if Lakshmi was the wife of the appellant then without divorcing her the appellant could not have validly married the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of nullity of Lakshmi finding; subsisting marriage renders second void under Hindu law.

holdings.text: A second wife whose marriage is void due to survival of first marriage is not a legally wedded wife entitled to maintenance under Section 125 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: However, under the law a second wife whose marriage is void on account of the survival of the first marriage is not a legally wedded wife, and is, therefore, not entitled to maintenance under this provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from definition of 'wife' in Explanation (b) and precedents like Vimala and Savitaben; strict proof needed for prior marriage.

holdings.text: Respondent cannot claim status of wife under Section 125 CrPC unless appellant's marriage to Lakshmi disproved.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have held that the Courts below erred in law in holding that Lakshmi was not married to the appellant since no notice was issued to her and she was not heard , it cannot be said at this stage that the respondent herein is the wife of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending valid determination on Lakshmi marriage; divorced wife covered but no marriage no claim.

holdings.text: 'Relationship in the nature of marriage' under PWDVA Section 2(f) akin to common law marriage requiring parties hold out as spouses, legal age, qualified to marry, voluntary cohabitation in shared household for significant period; mere live-in, weekends, one-night stand or keep does not qualify.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion a relationship in the nature of marriage is akin to a common law marriage. Common law marriages require that although not being formally married - The couple must hold themselves out to society as being akin to spouses. They must be of legal age to marry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation drawing analogy to US common law marriage and palimony concepts, listing essential elements for protection under PWDVA; distinguishes from casual relationships to prevent abuse.

holdings.text: Lower courts erred; their finding set aside, matter remanded to Family Court to issue notice to Lakshmi, hear her, and give fresh finding on appellant's marriage to her.

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the facts of the present case, we are of the opinion that the High Court and the learned Family Court Judge erred in law in holding that the appellant was not married to Lakshmi without even issuing notice to Lakshmi. Hence this finding has to be set aside and the matter remanded to the Family Court which may issue notice to Lakshmi and after hearing her give a fresh finding in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural error in violating natural justice necessitates remand for proper adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, since Lakshmi was not made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and no notice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis-- vis the appellant is wholly null and void as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice.

Coming back to the facts of the present case, we are of the opinion that the High Court and the learned Family Court Judge erred in law in holding that the appellant was number married to Lakshmi without even issuing numberice to Lakshmi. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion a relationship in the nature of marriage is akin to a common law marriage. Common law marriages require that although not being formally married - The couple must hold themselves out to society as being akin to spouses. They must be of legal age to marry.
